BOB FIELD: I'm Bob Field.

I have been called one of the
grand old men of spectroscopy.

The reason for that is I'm old. But I also have unconventional
views of what spectroscopy is

and what's interesting
in spectroscopy.

Before we get started, I
want to tell you what the--

the formal requirements
for the course will be. There will be some
occasional homeworks.

Not one a week, or maybe
not even two a week. But when I come up with a
good problem, I'll assign it.

There's going to be frequent
5-minute quizzes at the end

of the hour, where the idea is-- [INAUDIBLE] a concept
and you'll just

use it to do something
really trivial with it while it's still hot. And I find that that's a good
way of actually realizing

whether you learned
something or not. And it's useful for me also to
see whether I was successful.

there will be a project
at the end, where what I will try to do is to get
you to use some of the concepts

in the course to write a not
trivial quasi paper, which

might even be publishable. And this would be
a collaboration

among two or three people. Because maybe one is good
at writing code, and what is good at deriving
the equations, and one

is good at writing or something
like that, but we'll see.

The final thing will be a
brief oral exam, one on one,

where I'll ask you
a few questions. And look, I have to have
some formal requirements.

This is a course with a grade. And these are all things
that make it possible

for me to take this seriously. But I'm not going to
try to humiliate anybody

in an oral exam. I mean, this would be you
just come to my office and talk to me for a
few minutes, maybe 15.

And there will be
also some reading. OK, so I have a very
unconventional view

of spectroscopy. And I hope that this
is-- well, first of all, this course is a
version of a course

I gave for the first
22 years I was at MIT. And it does have in it my
unique view of spectroscopy.

This book by Peter Bernhardt,
who was one of my students, is a very conventional
view of spectroscopy.

And if you feel indigestion
from my crazy stuff, you can look at this and it'll
bring it all down to Earth.

There are two other
books that have been extremely important to me
in my professional development.

One of them is
[INAUDIBLE],, which is just a beautiful book
about atomic spectrum.

And everything that I know
about electronic structure, of molecules, really
comes from this book.

And it's a wonderful book. When I was a postdoc, I
made the arrogant statement

that this little book by
Jon Hougen, The Calculation of Rotational Energy
Levels and Rotational Light

Intensity in Diatomic
Molecules, contained everything that you needed to know in all
three of [INAUDIBLE] books.

That's ridiculous, but it's
not completely ridiculous.

So there is some-- 49 pages, which really is
the minimal introduction

to my kind of spectroscopy. This book is now
available online, so you don't even have
to steal it from me.

You can just go to the
National Institute of-- the NIST website and find it.

This is my book. This is the book on small
molecule spectroscopy. And so anything I say
is probably in here.

And this is a
telephone directory. And many people feel that
spectroscopy is a bunch--

is just collecting a
bunch of numbers that resemble a telephone directory. And small molecule
spectroscopists are not held

in very high esteem, because
people think what we do is

write telephone
directories and we don't. And what I'm going to
try to do in this course

is to convince you that
there's some beautiful patterns

and there's some codes
that we can break. And we'll learn a
great deal, that's

far more interesting than
telephone directories. OK, so, the main things
that I'm going to teach you,

there is the language
of spectroscopy. There is an elaborate notation.

And many people get stuck,
either by the telephone directory aspect or by this--

what appears to be
impenetrable notation. It's very concise.

It's very elegant. And it has a kind of
ability to describe things

at different levels of
how much do we know. So normally, you can
describe something

if you understand it perfectly. But spectroscopy has a
way of describing things

at the beginning of
understanding, all the way up to a complete picture.

And so the language is not
just a boring little thing. And I will refer to it often.

There are also toy models. In fact, everything
is spectroscopy starts

with toy models. In other words, we know
about rigid rotors. We know about
harmonic oscillators.

We know about Rydberg-- the hydrogen atom. We know about the hydrogen
2 plus molecular ion.

We have a lot of
simple models that we use to describe energy levels.

And spectroscopy really involves
tying all those models together

in some imaginative way. And I also want to
stress that this is not

about the exact Hamiltonian. That we build an
effective Hamiltonian that

represents the spectrum and
the dynamics in the spectrum, which is made out
of these toy models.

And many of you, who are
interested in theory, are interested in doing
exact calculations.

But for spectroscopy,
the exact calculations are often the direct path
to the telephone directory.

Because they're numbers without
mechanism, without description. They're description
without causality.

Often, good theorists do distill
from the exact Hamiltonian mechanism.

But the emphasis is
usually on exact. And here, we're going to be
talking about toy models that

are built from-- that are connected
together and we then use them to explain
the spectrum.

And of course,
perturbation theory is going to be very important
in these toy models.

Now, in perturbation
theory, we're

going to have a lot of things
we call matrix elements. Those of you who know about
the matrix picture, quantum

mechanics, know what that means. Can I use the language of
matrix elements for everybody?
Is everybody happy with that? OK.

Now, there are two ways in which
matrix elements are evaluated.

One is that we have scaling-- we have rules, selection
rules for which ones are zero.

And we often have scaling
rules for how one matrix element is related to another.

And so if we know
one fact, we can generate a huge number
of related facts

through those sorts of things. So there's the structure
of the matrix elements

and then there is the process
of evaluating matrix elements. The value of this
integral accumulates

in a very special
region of space. And there is great insight
often in figuring out

where does a matrix
element acquire its value.

And so the concept
of stationary phase is going to play a key
role in all of this.

OK, so we have
language, toy models. We have intensities.

And when we start talking
about intensities, there are several
different issues.

Now, I do hope you'll
interrupt me and ask me to amplify on things,
but right now I'm

just making long lists. But I'm going to ask you
guys a question soon.

In fact, it's in this
little article over here. OK, so when we talk
about intensities,

we have the concept of bright
states and dark states.

This is a very important
concept in spectroscopy. And you've probably heard it--

heard the term used, but
you wonder what it is. There are also things
called propensity rules.

And there are things like
Franck-Condon factors.

And there's two kinds of
Franck-Condon factors. There's evaluate a [INAUDIBLE]
integral and square interval.

And there is the semi-classical,
or the classical Franck-Condon factor, which is directly
related to this number.

But most people don't think
about Franck-Condon factors as classical
mechanical quantities.

We hear the word semi-classical,
or the expression. What does semi-classical mean? Does anybody want to tell me
what semi-classical means?

AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE] of the
system classically [INAUDIBLE]..

BOB FIELD: That's not
what I mean by it. But that's a very good answer.
Does anybody else want to try?

AUDIENCE: So you take
a classical formulation and then you add the certain
parts to it, which resemble

[INAUDIBLE]. BOB FIELD: I think you've
got almost all of it. I would have started from
quantum mechanics, where

we're saying, in quantum
mechanics we can have--

we can specify coordinates. But then you can't
specify momentum.

And in the
semi-classical approach, one says, well, we
use, say, coordinates

and we can then use
classical mechanics to specify what the classical
momentum would be at any point.

And these ideas of bringing
in classical mechanics

and using this to explain
quantum mechanics.

Because-- wave [INAUDIBLE]
is going to have nodes.

The spacing-- the spatial
spacing between nodes are related to the momentum.

But if we're talking
about coordinates, we're not allowed to
talk about momentum. But we can.

And the beauty of
semi-classical approach is that we can
talk about whatever

we want by going this
classical mechanics. And then use that for
insights or to make

important approximations
of key quantities. AUDIENCE: So is one example
of that the vibration

of the molecule, that
molecules spend more time here as turning points. And so things are more
likely to happen there.

Is that an example-- BOB FIELD: Well, that's
part of it, but-- AUDIENCE: Is that an example
of the semi-classical? BOB FIELD: But one of the-- I would say the
most important thing

is, where is the first node? How far do you have to
go from the turning point
into the first node? And how far are the nodes apart?

Because that's where you
discover where integrals accumulate. You get stationary
phase, stationary phase--

it's a mixture of
quantum mechanics and classical mechanics. So-- OK, so, we're going
to be talking about models

for how things work. We're going to talk
about intensities.

And I'm going to teach
you how to assign spectra.

Well, this is something
which those of you

who are not in my
research group, are going to
wonder, why is that? I never heard about that.

No textbook ever talks about
how you would assign spectra. Spectra are not born
with assignments on them.

There is some trick,
something that enables you to say this
transition has these quantums.

And we do it-- well, quantum
numbers are how many nodes does a wave function
have and where are--

how are the nodal
surfaces organized. But there is no
way, experimentally,

to observe nodes or to
observe the wave function. So, how do we make
assignments based on things

we can't observe directly? And it's based on the existence
of patterns and the ability

to somehow disentangle
various patterns. And so, this is not a
trivial and boring thing.

This is the essence
of what we do and all insight comes
from the assignments.

And often, you have to
design an experiment which makes the assignments clear. So I'm going to talk
about assigning spectra.
And OK--

Now, in 574 there is a rigorous
treatment of the interaction

of light with matter. I'm not going to
talk about that. I'm going to be talking
about radiation as photons,

like bullets. And so, I'm not going to be
talking about experiments

or how you rigorously
design an experiment. I'm going to be talking
mostly about the energy

levels, the Hamiltonian, and how
you interact with that, but not

so much how do you do clever
things with the system. So, photons as bullets,
not the correct treatment.

And the last issue
is how is dynamics
encoded in frequency domain.

This is an interesting issue,
because in the frequency

domain, one is looking
at eigenstates. And eigenstates don't move.

So what do we mean by dynamics? But I will show you, or
insist, that dynamics--

any time you have a data
set with a lot of structure, you can use that to break
a code and to say, oh, yeah

the dynamics is encoded in
this complicated data set, whether it's a time domain or
a frequency domain data set.

And I will show you how
to break those codes. OK, so that's the
general outline.

And now I'm going to talk
about some of the models that you're going to use.

Rotation-- well, everybody
knows what rotation is, that's a rigid rotor. And the rigid rotor has
an energy level formula,

some constant times an integer,
times and integer, plus 1. That's a very familiar thing.

Now, we can generalize. We can do things that are more
complicated than rigid rotor. We can do a symmetric
top or an asymmetric top.

But one of the simplest
things in spectroscopy is the rotational
degree of freedom. I can deal with all rotation
for all conceivable molecules

in about two [INAUDIBLE]. But rotation is
an important part, because that's where we
get a lot of the patterns.

And in fact, the rotation
often provides you some hidden information about
the symmetries of things.
OK, and then we have vibration.

And we are very happy
with harmonic oscillators.

Everything that has small
displacements from equilibrium is a harmonic oscillator.

And so that's a pattern that
we're going to use a lot, even when it's not true,
even when the oscillators are

neither harmonic nor uncoupled. But we're going to
describe vibration in terms
of harmonic oscillators. Then we're going to couple them. And we'll deal with both--

we'll deal with anharmonicity
on two [INAUDIBLE].. One is within one oscillator
and between oscillators.

And the tool for dealing with
that is perturbation theory. Now, the hardest problem of
all is the electronic one.

But again, we have
some simple models to describe the
electronic [INAUDIBLE]..

We have hydrogen.
We have helium. We have H2 plus, and we have
the particle of the box.

This one, this one,
and this one are things

that you've all thought about. And so hydrogen atom gives us
Rydberg states, Rydberg series.

And that actually turns out
to be a model for electron scattering off of something.

Because there are an infinite
number of more or less identical Rydberg state. So hydrogen atom is extremely
important in our understanding

of electronic structure. But it's really much less
important than the helium atom

and H2 plus. But the particle in the box
is also really important,

because it tells us
the size effects. And so, if you know how
the energy levels scale

with the length of
the box and the mass, you know an awful lot about--

well, electrons always
have the same mass unless you're in solids. But we're talking about
gas based systems,

so the electron has the
same mass, but the size-- the space available to it is
a crucial interpretive thing.

OK, so H2 plus gives us
LCA, Linear Combination

of Atomic orbitals to
make molecular orbitals. And this is an extremely
valuable zero order picture

for valence states of molecules. But this is for Rydberg
states of molecules.

And helium provides
us with exchange.

So helium tells us
the beginning of how do electrons talk to each other,
as well as to the nuclear.

And so these four paradigms
provide us with everything we need to deal with
electronic structure.
OK, now I have another question.

How big is an orbital? How do we know-- what's
the size of an orbital?

infinite, but let's say, OK,

the full width at half maximum? OK, so that's a

but it's not what I want. And I'm up here and
I got control here. So we have some kind of
a distribution of charge

and it does go to infinity,
although that's really not important, but
where is half of it?

So do we have some
simple way of estimating

the size of an orbital? The next question would be,
well, how would we measure?

How do you measure
a wave function? You don't measure
a wave function. So, having a simple way of
deciding on how big something
is is really valuable. Because you can't measure it.

You can measure things
that are related to it, but how do you-- so how do
we make a decision about how
big an orbital is? Anybody want to tell me?

We can use one of
these paradigms to describe how
big an orbital is.

This one would be really

there's a certain
energy that you can add and the electron is then free. So this is the wrong thing.

This is needlessly complicated. This doesn't have the-- this is not round and so
maybe we should use this.

putting together things that

you normally wouldn't put
together, but you'd get-- from the energy flow
ionization, you get the size.
And how do you get the size? You use the two formulas.

So this is the distance
below ionization. And that's equal to the Rydberg

OK, but you don't

And we have from

we have a formula, the
[INAUDIBLE] radius over 2,

OK, then you solve

And we stick-- so

energy is, you know

the energy below ionization. This is a constant. So, this is a way of
getting n, which we then
put into this formula. And we get the size.

And so you had it
absolutely right. If you know what the
ionzation energy is,

then you can say, OK, from
how far you are below it determines the size.

If you're far below, it's small. If you're up high, it's big. And this is a
really useful thing

for finding your way
around complicated systems. You always want to find a
way to estimate a quantity

or to estimate how
something should scale. And one of the things you're
always doing is trying

to find out, is this too crude? And usually, the most naive
concepts work really well.

AUDIENCE: But how is
this radius of an orbital related to any
molecular property?

Because this is of
a hydrogen atom. If you stick to hydrogen
atoms together, does-- BOB FIELD: Well, you still
have how far is the energy--

how bound is that electron? You're pulling off an

Well, actually, you
can be more specific. Suppose you know the
ionization energy

to the ground state of the ion. And maybe there's some

Then you could ask, OK, how
big are different orbitals? Not just the highest
occupied molecular orbital,

but some other one. And all of these work
at least, qualitatively.

So it doesn't matter
that it's not round. It really matters
how far is it below.

And especially if you're up
at relatively high energy. That orbitals are pretty round.

agree with that. But I'm saying, let's say

if I add that together,

But H2 is pretty spherical. And so maybe you make

or the center of charge

the center of charge

and the center of mass
are almost coincident.

So it's really, really

Because they tell you how

again, go through and talk about the various classes
of [INAUDIBLE] And does

AUDIENCE: Half way. BOB FIELD: Halfway, OK. I can do this properly. OK, so one of the real problems
is many electronic systems

or electronic structure-- and when most of us
decided to be chemists

it was when we saw in freshman
chemistry the periodic table

and discovered that very
simple concepts enabled us to make predictions
about the properties of all
of the atoms in isolation. And that is very beautiful.
So we have a periodic table.

We have the properties
of the isolated atoms. As soon as we start
looking at details

about the spectra of atoms or
the properties of molecules, we lose almost all of this.

But for atoms, for
many electron atoms,

we have a way of
dealing with this. We have orbitals,
configurations,

and LSJ electronic
states, which are called
by spectroscopists terms.

And I try to use the
correct language. So we have orbitals,
configurations, and terms.

And the orbitals
are the things that ought to exhibit periodicity. But the things we observe are
energy levels and they don't.

And so one of the ways in which
we recover the periodic table

is we calculate
electronic properties.
This is orbital energies.

This is a spin orbit
coupling constant. This is a Coulomb integral.

These are one
electron properties, these are two
electron properties, and this is an
exchange intergal. And so one can represent the
energy levels of the LSJ states

that belong to a
configuration by looking at these quantities and these
quantities exhibit periodicity.

So periodicity goes away, but
in the effective Hamiltonian,

or in the Hamiltonian we use
to describe the energy levels, we have the quantities, all
of which show periodicity.

So we haven't lost it. Now, we do have trouble when
we start going to molecules.

But that's just an
interesting thing. And I will be talking about
some of this archaic stuff,

that when you have exact
quantum mechanics, why do you bother with thinking
about these quantities,

but it's because what I want
is not a telephone directory.

you say that you still observe in the spectra [INAUDIBLE]
to the effect of having

a Hamiltonian, are
they effectively--

don't they have this

What's the difference between a

Now-- now, I really--

I'm a diatomic molecule person. And we do polyatonomic
molecules in my group, but most of the
things in my research

group I've gotten credit for as
being surprising and wonderful have to do with the vibrations
of polyatomic molecules,

but my first love is
diatomic molecules. And I really am one of the
great authorities in the world

on diatomic molecules. So I have to force myself not to
say too much about that topic.

So for diatomics,
we describe them

in terms of a rigid rotor
and a harmonic oscillator. And then we say, oh,
well, it's not rigid

and it's not quite harmonic,
and so we write an energy level
expression-- V is vibration, J is rotation.

And we write it as a sum
of what are called Dunham
constants, which multiply.

So we have a polynomial in
the vibrational quantum number and in the rotational
quantum numbers.

This is just self defense. This isn't anything significant. If we just say, OK,
we have energy levels

and we're going to
have to represent by some kind of a power series. And so, we might
well be reasonably

intelligent about
what the power is of. But these are just
numbers that are used

to represent the energy level. And there is another
set of numbers where--

is different from
every other molecule. And we have an
expression in terms

of polynomials in
displacement from equilibrium.

This is also Dunham. It's saying, well, we
could represent anything in terms of a power series.

And so, we have two
different representations, one of the energy
level structure

and one of the
essential thing that makes one molecule different
from another potential energy

curve. And what we'd really
like is some kind of way of relating these
things to these things.

And Mr. Dunham worked that out
by doing semi-classical quantum

mechanics. And it's really old that
it's really archaic.

And there's another
way of doing this and that's using
perturbation theory.

And I'll do a lot of that. So if you have a spectrum which
you've assigned and determined

a bunch of these
Dunham constants, then you can invert
that to a potential.

If you have a potential
and you say, well, I'm going to truncate this,
I'm going to represent it

quadratic, cubic,
plus [INAUDIBLE]---- forget [INAUDIBLE] and higher,
well then I can take these

and calculate all of these,
just using perturbation theory. That's something I love to do.

And so you'll do it. But for diatomics,
there's also a thing

called Rydberg-Klein-Rees. It's a way of taking
the energy levels,

these things, or
more specifically the vibrational energy levels,
and the rotational constants,

two expressions. Again, it's power theory. These two things, you get
the potential energy curve

numerically by
another consequence of semi-classical quantum
mechanics, the WKP.

So for diatomic
molecules, because you

have both G of B and B
of B, and because they're one dimensional
potentials, this works.

For polyatomic
molecules, forget it.  And so the perturbation
theory is the only thing

that you can use. So there's a lot of testing
of how good is perturbation

theory, how good is
RKR, by going back and forth between these two. But the only tool
you have for dealing

with vibrations in polyphonic
molecules is pervasive theory.

And sometimes you use RKR as a
way of checking or extending,

but since you don't have-- it's not one
dimensional, there's no way of getting
the full inversion.

And so this gives you
actually distances between turning points. And this gives you a way of
finding what the actual turning
points are. But that's beside the point. I'm getting in too deep. OK, so we have vibrations.

Now, diatomic molecules
have the wonderful habit

of not always being in
sigma, sigma, plus states.

Now, when you see
a symbol like this,

that's called not 3 pi, but
triplet pi, [INAUDIBLE]..

But this is how you
describe a state. You multiply-- you mention
its multiplicity, 2s plus 1.

You mention its projection
of orbital angular momentum on the symmetry axis.

And perhaps some other
group theoretical arcana like the reflection
symmetry in a plane

that contains the inner
nuclear axis or inversion at the center of mass.

So there are extra
symbols on these things. But the formulas
that you all expect

to be obeyed by
diatomic molecule

reflect that there is no spin
or orbital angular momentum. And that you just have a simple
state that's closed shell,

is behaving without
any complexity. But a triplet pi state
is like six of these.

But we don't call them six
states, we call it one state. Because there are relationships
among the components
of a triplet pi. And they're very easy to impose.

And they also provide important
details on what kind of a state

is this. From the pattern
of states, you can determine whether it's pi,
whether it's G, whether there

is a nearby sigma state. There's all sorts of
details in the deviations

from simple sigma, sigma, plus
like structure that tell you what's really interesting.

And so when we have
states with non-zero spin

and with non-zero projection of
the orbital angular momentum. And then we get into
things called Hund's cases.

Now, Hund's cases is second
only to hyperfied structure as a sleeping pill.

When people hear
Hund's cases are electric quadrupole
coupling counts,

they immediately know
they should go to sleep. But it turns out that both of
those things are good for you,

better than cod liver oil. Hund's cases are just a way
of taking from the spectrum

a simple pattern. But there are several
different patterns, depending on the relative
size of the not roundness

of the electronic structure,
the spin orbit coupling constant, and the rotation.

We got three things and they can
be arranged in any of six ways.

And out of that comes five
Hund's coupling cases, because one of them is
impossible to achieve.

And so-- but what you get in the
limits of one thing being large compared to another
is a regular pattern

that you can
recognize and exploit to make sense of the spectrum. So these coupling
cases are really

useful in that often a molecule
isn't at one of those limits.

And so you have to
build a model that allows it not to
be at that limit and still assign the spectrum.
